friend_mood: feeling afraid because my friend had been looking at pictures of car crashes. Now, she is afraid to drive anywhere. Seriously, she can hardly go anywhere a car might be.
your_strategy: sympathizing, suggesting
history:
friend: I have been looking at pictures of crazy car crashes.
me: Oh really? Any interesting ones?
friend: Seriously now I can't drive anywhere. I can't even leave the house for fear of car crash
me: I see, that sounds like a real challenge. Maybe we could try to distract yourself from these images and focus on something else. Would you like to go for a walk instead?
friend: Yes, I'll try. But I don't know if I can go far, maybe just around the block.
me: That's a great start. Let's take it step by step and try to build up your confidence little by little.
friend: Thank you, I appreciate your help.
me: Of course! And if you ever need to talk about it, I'm here for you.
friend: Thanks.

### Example 2
# Mood
My friend's mood: feeling sad because he lost his

friend_mood: feeling trusting because my friend thinks having faith in someone is important in life. She has that with her husband without a doubt.
your_strategy: sharing or relating to own experience, expressing care or concern
history:
friend: I think that my husband and me have so much faith in each other.
me: thats awesome to hear, a lot of people cheat on each other frequently and dont care anymore
friend: I know, I cant do that. I think it's very important to be honest in your love li
me: That's really nice to hear, I agree that faithfulness is a key component of a successful relationship.
friend: Yes, and I'm glad that my husband feels the same way.
me: Have you guys been married long?
friend: Yes, we've been married for 10 years.
me: Wow, that's amazing. I hope I can find someone to have that kind of trust and faith in.
friend: Well, it takes time and effort, but it's worth it.
me: I couldn't agree more.
friend: How about you? Are you seeing anyone?
me: Not currently, but I'm keeping an open mind and staying positive.

friend_mood: feeling excited because his wife is coming back home after being out of the country for 2 months.
your_strategy: encouraging, sympathizing, sharing own thoughts/opinion, expressing care or concern
history:
friend: My wife is coming home after being out of the country for 2 months.  I can't wait!
me: You must be really excited!
friend: I am!  We've never been apart this long, so it's been tou
me: That's great news! I'm glad she's coming home soon.
friend: Yeah, me too. It's going to be nice to have her back.
me: I know how it feels to miss someone, but at least you guys have a strong bond.
friend: Yes, we do.
me: Have you planned anything special for her coming home?
friend: Not really, just a simple dinner and some gifts.
me: That's really sweet. I hope everything goes well and you both have a wonderful time together.
friend: Thanks! I hope the same for you.

friend_mood: feeling prepared because my friend used to live in California. Early one morning, they had a smallish earthquake. It made him realize he had not put together an emergency package, so he immediately did so. He believes it never hurts to be ready for the Big One!
your_strategy: acknowledging or admitting, changing the subject
history:

me: wow, it must have been quite an experience
friend: It was enough to wake me, but not the cat, lol. It just made me realize that the Big One could happen any time and I would have been up the proverbial cre
me: That's great that you've got yourself covered, I guess. But hey, how about we talk about something else? What have you been up to lately?
friend: Well, I've been thinking a lot about the future and what I want to do with my life. Have you ever thought about what you want to do?
me: I've been thinking about that too, actually. I've been considering a career change.
friend: That's a big decision! Have you thought about what you want to do?
me: Yes, I have. And I think I'd like to become a chef.
friend: That's awesome! You're good in the kitchen.
me: Thanks! I'll need to take

friend_mood: feeling lonely because my friend feels so lonely because he/she is all by himself/herself.
your_strategy: sympathizing, encouraging
history:
friend: I am so lonely because I am all by myself
me: Aw, I'm sorry, well I'm here to talk to you! 
friend: I appreciate that. It's just tough because I go daily without talking to anyone. It's nice to talk to some
me: I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling lonely. Is there anything specific that's been making you feel this way lately?
friend: Yeah, it's just that I don't have anyone to talk to daily. It's nice to talk to someone though.
me: That's completely understandable. Sometimes it's hard to keep up connections, especially during these times. Have you tried joining any online communities or groups where you could connect with other people who share similar interests?
friend: No, I haven't. I'll give it a try. Thanks for the suggestion!
me: Of course! Let me know how it goes and if there's anything else I can do to support you

friend_mood: feeling anticipating because my friend is so eager for her son to be born, she cannot wait.
your_strategy: sympathizing, sharing own thoughts/opinion, relating to own experience
history:
friend: I am so excited for my baby son to be born, I am so eager for it to happen!
me: Oh man, your life is about to get so much more hectic. I feel for you. When my first was born, I was just as pumped, full of naivety and positivity. I felt like I could take on anything coming my way. I was exhausted after two weeks. It's such a long ride until they're able to even remotely look after themselves.
friend: I know! Hopefully the stress levels are kept to a minimal and I have a very supporting husband who will be there every step of the way. I hope for a swift and trouble free bir
me: I completely understand how you're feeling right now. Childbirth is an amazing experience, but it can also be quite overwhelming.
friend: Yes, I know. I'm hoping for a smooth and quick delivery.
me: I remember feeling the same way when my child was born. It's a beautiful experience, but it does come with its challenges. How about we focus on the positives and make sure we have all the necessary support in place?
friend: That sounds like a great plan! Thanks for the encouragement.
me: Of course, I'm always here for you!
friend: I really appreciate it.
me: No problem, I'm just happy for you and wishing you the best of luck!
friend: Thank

friend_mood: feeling disappointed because my friend was really down after he found out that he was not going to be able to move.
your_strategy: encouraging, questioning for details
history:
friend: I was really down after I found out that I was not going to be able to move.
me: Why? How did that happen?
friend: Becaue I am stuck at a mine site and no one will buy me out. No one wants to live at a mine site with land collapsing everywher
me: That sounds tough. But it's amazing that you're still holding on despite the challenges. Do you mind sharing more details about the situation and how you've been dealing with it?
friend: I've been here for a long time. It's not easy, but I've been managing. I just hope I can find a way out soon.
me: I'm sure you will. Maybe we could brainstorm some ideas together?
friend: That would be great! Thank you for listening.
me: Of course! I'm here for you.
friend: Thanks.

friend_mood: feeling proud because my friend recently hit a new personal record at the gym!

history:

me: That is a great accomplishment. I admire your dedication in obtaining that goal.
friend: Thank you! I didn't feel like I would ever be able to do it, but consistency does seem to pay o

friend: yeah, I guess you're right. I'll have to talk to him about it.
me: I hope it all works out for the best.
friend: thanks for listening, I really appreciate it.
me: Of course, anytime.

me: I will try my best, thanks for your concern.

me: You too, have a great day.

me: That must be really frustrating. Have you tried talking to someone higher up in the organization to get some help?
friend: I did, but they just keep telling me to work around it and that it's not a priority right now.
me: I can imagine how that feels. Sometimes, things like this just happen, and it's out of our control. Maybe we can try to find some workarounds or alternative methods to accomplish the tasks that the system is making difficult?
friend: Yes, I've been trying to do that. But it's not ideal and takes a lot more time than it should.

friend_mood: feeling afraid because one time, someone came to my friend's door with a gun. He wanted money, but my friend didn't have any, so the person stole some items from the house.
your_strategy: sympathizing, expressing care or concern
history:

me: What did you do in response?
friend: I called the police after he robbed 
me: That must have been a terrifying experience for you. I'm really sorry that happened to you.
friend: Yes, I was really scared. I'm still shaken up about it.
me: Have you taken any steps to ensure your safety since then?
friend: Yes, I have installed a security system and I'm keeping a closer eye on my surroundings.
me: That's great to hear. I'll keep you in my thoughts and hope that everything goes well from now on.
friend: Thank you, I appreciate your support.

me: Of course! Let's catch up soon and celebrate when you finally get that promotion.

me: That's fantastic! I've heard a lot about their work too. Have you ever volunteered there before?
friend: Yes, I have. I love spending time with the animals and helping them out.
me: That's really nice. I used to volunteer at a dog shelter when I was younger. I loved it, it was such a rewarding experience.
friend: I agree. Volunteering is a great way to give back to the community.
me: Absolutely! Good luck on Sunday.

friend: Yes, we are really looking forward to it.

me: Of course. And hey, maybe it's time for us to go out and do something fun to cheer ourselves up, what do you think?
friend: That's a great idea. Let's go!

me: Anytime, friend.  Let me know if there's anything else I can do to help.

friend: I did! The company does something that I actually like -- a panel interview vs a series of one-on-ones. Have you ever had an interview like th
me: Wow, that's amazing! Congrats on getting the job! I've never had a panel interview before. How did you find it different from a series of one-on-one interviews?
friend: It was actually a lot easier for me because I could address each panel member individually. It also helped that everyone seemed to be very friendly. What about you? Have you ever had a panel interview?
me: Nope, but I've had some group interviews. They can be intimidating, but they also allow you to showcase your teamwork skills. I'm really happy for you, and I wish you the best of luck in your new role!
